Question: In India, who appoints the Advocate General of a State?
Solution:
The correct answer is
Key Points
  • Advocate General of states:
    • Article 165 of the Constitution talks about the Advocate General of states.
    • He is the highest law officer in the state.
    • He assists the state government in all its legal matters.
    • The Governor of each State shall appoint a person who is qualified to be appointed a Judge of a High Court to be an Advocate-General for the State.
    • The Advocate-General shall hold office at the pleasure of the Governor.
    • He shall receive such remuneration as the Governor may determine.
  • Governor of the state:
    • He is the constitutional head of the state.
    • He is appointed by the president.
    • He must have at least 35 years of age to become a governor.
Additional Information
  • The Prime Minister of India
    • The Prime Minister of India is the leader of the executive of the Government of India.
    • The prime minister is also the chief adviser to the President of India and head of the Council of Ministers.
    • She/he can be a member of any of the two houses of the Parliament of India, the Lok Sabha (House of the People) and the Rajya Sabha (Council of the States).
  • President of India: He is the supreme commander of the Indian armed forces.
    • The qualifications to become a president are:
      • He should be a citizen of India,
      • He must have completed 35 years of age.
      • He must be qualified to become a member of the Lok Sabha.
      • He should not hold any office of profit under the Union or state government.
  • Chief Minister of the state:
    • The Chief Minister of the state of India is the 'elected' head of the government and the executive authority lies with the Chief Minister.
    • He is appointed by the respective State Governor.

Question: When did the Constitution of WHO come into force - a date which we now celebrate as World Health Day every year?
Solution:
The correct answer is 7 April 1948.
Key Points
  • World Health Day is celebrated on 7 April every year.
  • It was decided to celebrate World Health Day in 1948 in the First Health Assembly of the World Health Organization.
  • It was first celebrated in 1950.
  • It is one of the 11 official global health campaigns announced by WHO.​​
Additional Information
  • World Health Organization:
    • Founded – April 7, 1948
    • Headquarters – Geneva, Switzerland
    • Parent Organization – United Nations Economic and Social Council
    • Objective – Highest possible health level for all human beings
    • Publication – World Health Report
    • Regional offices – Brazzaville (Congo), Copenhagen (Denmark), New Delhi (India), Cairo (Egypt), Manila (The Philippines), Washington D.C. (US)

Question: India was named ‘Bharat’ after the name of the Bharat tribe. In which of the following Vedas is this tribe first mentioned?
Solution:
The correct answer is Rigveda.
Key Points Bharatas were the Vedic tribe mentioned in Rigveda. The name Bharata was used for a group of people who lived in the northwest, and who are mentioned in the Rigveda, the earliest composition in Sanskrit. Later it was used for the country.
  • Vedic Period
    • It is the period in the late Bronze age and early Iron Age of the History of India when the Vedas were composed in the northern Indian subcontinent.
    • The associated culture was referred to as Vedic Civilization.
    • The entire Earth was called the Bharatvarsha but in particular, the area that lied south to the Himalayan Mountain was called the Bharatvarsha.
    • The Bharatvarsha was also known as Aryavarta meaning the land of Aryans.
    • Aryavarta and Bharat are mentioned in Vedas, many scriptures, and Mahabharata.
    • Bharatas were the Vedic tribe mentioned in Rigveda.​
Additional Information
  • Rig Veda:
    • The oldest Veda is the Rigveda.
    • It has 1028 hymns called ‘Suktas’ and is a collection of 10 books called Mandalas.
    • The meaning of the word ‘Rigveda’ is Praise Knowledge.
    • Rigvedic books 2-9 deal with cosmology and deities.
    • Rigvedic books 1 and 10 deal with philosophical questions and also talk about various virtues including charity in society.
    • The meters used to form hymns are Gayatri, Anushtubh, Trishtubh, and Jagati (Trishtubh and Gayatri are most important).
  • Sama Veda:
    • Known as the Veda of melodies and chants, Samaveda dates back to 1200-800 BCE.
    • This Veda is related to public worship. T
    • here are 1549 verses (except 75 verses, all have been taken from Rigveda).
    • There are two Upanishads embedded in Samaveda – Chandogya Upanishad and Kena Upanishad.
    • Samaveda Samhita is not meant to be read as a text, it is like a musical score sheet that must be heard.
  • ​Yajur Veda:
    • Stands to mean ‘Worship Knowledge’.
    • Yajurveda dates back to 1100-800 BCE.
    • It compiles ritual-offering mantras/chants. These chants were offered by the priest alongside a person who used to perform a ritual (in most cases yajna fire.)
    • It has two types – Krishna (Black/Dark) & Shukla (White/Bright). Krishna Yajurveda has an un-arranged, unclear, motley collection of verses and Shukla Yajurveda has arranged and clear verses.
  • ​Atharva Veda:
    • Stands to mean a tatpurusha compound of Atharvan, an ancient sage, and knowledge.
    • It dates back to 1000-800 BCE.
    • It has 730 hymns/suktas, 6000 mantras, and 20 books.

Question: What do you call the drugs that bind to the receptor site and inhibit its natural function?
Solution:
The correct answer is Antagonists.
Key Points
  • Antagonists
    • Drugs that bind to the receptor site and inhibit its natural function are called Antagonists.
    • Antagonists and agonists act differently.
    • Agonists combine with the receptor molecule and produce a biological response but antagonists combine with the receptors and inhibit their natural function.
    • Enzyme inhibitors inhibit the catalytic activity of the enzyme.
Additional Information
  • Antidepressants
    • Antidepressants are medications prescribed to treat various forms of depression and anxiety disorders.
    • They work by affecting neurotransmitters in the brain, such as serotonin, norepinephrine, and dopamine, which play a role in mood regulation.
  • Agonist
    • An agonist is a molecule or compound that activates a receptor, leading to a physiological or pharmacological response in a cell or organism.
    • Agonists can be naturally occurring, like hormones or neurotransmitters, or synthetic, like drugs.
  • Depressants
    • Depressants are substances that slow down the central nervous system (CNS), reducing neural activity and leading to relaxation, drowsiness, and decreased alertness.
    • They can have therapeutic uses, such as treating anxiety, insomnia, and muscle spasms.
    • Common depressants include alcohol, benzodiazepines (e.g., Valium, Xanax), barbiturates, and certain sleep medications.

Question:
Which of the following statements is/are CORRECT with respect to Draft Information Technology (Intermediary Guidelines and Digital Media Ethics Code) Rules, 2021, proposed in 2022?
A. Online games will have to register with a self-regulatory body, and only games cleared by the body will be allowed to legally operate in India.
B. Online gaming companies will not be allowed to engage in betting on the outcome of games, the proposed rules say.
C. According to the rules, there could be more than one self-regulatory body.
Solution:
Correct Answer A, B and C
Key Points
  • Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology (MEITY) has released the draft rules pertaining to online gaming by amending the Information Technology (Intermediary Guidelines and Digital Media Ethics Code) Rules, 2021.
  • These rules are released by MEITY for the comments of the public and shall remain open for such comments till 17th Jan. 2023.
  • he proposed rules add definitions for online games and online gaming intermediaries and put restrictions on games related to betting, gambling, or the participation of minors.
  • Online gaming intermediaries will need to register with a self-regulatory body, which must be registered with the Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology, and must display their registration details on their website or mobile application.
  • The self-regulatory body will be composed of several individuals with different backgrounds, and the online gaming intermediary must display a visible mark of registration on all online games registered by the self-regulatory body.
  • Gaming companies will also have to secure a Random Number Generation Certificate to ensure game outputs are statistically random and unpredictable, and a "no bot certificate" from a reputed certifying body.
  • Online intermediaries will be required to identify and verify the identity of the user (KYC) while starting a user account-based relationship.
  • They will also need to appoint a Chief Compliance Officer, a nodal contact person, and publish a physical contact address in India on their website or mobile application.
Additional Information Why in the news?
  • Social media platforms and other intermediaries on the Internet are now required to remove PIB-flagged fake news articles about the Union Government from their platforms.
  • The new amendment of the IT Rules means that Social media platforms will no longer enjoy legal immunity on content posted by their users.
    • Platforms can now be called as a party in court proceedings. Hence statement 1 is correct.
    • Minister of State for Electronics and Information Technology said that platforms will not be required to take down content due to this Rule alone, but they will not enjoy the legal immunity that they currently benefit from for content posted by their users. They can now be called as a party in court proceedings.
  • The changes were notified through the Information Technology (Intermediary Guidelines and Digital Media Ethics Code) Amendment Rules, 2023, amending the IT Rules, 2021.
Information Technology (Intermediary Guidelines and Digital Media Ethics Code) Amendment Rules, 2023:
  • Social Media Platforms:
    • The rules require social media platforms with a certain number of users in the country to establish a physical presence, including a registered office, in the country.
    • This aims to ensure that these platforms are more accountable to the laws and regulations of the country and can be held liable for any content that violates the rules.
  • Content Removal and Traceability:
    • The rules mandate social media platforms to remove or disable access to any unlawful content or information.a
    • They are also required to maintain records of the origin of information, which can be used to trace the originator of any unlawful content.
    • This is aimed at combating the spread of fake news, misinformation, and illegal content online.
  • User verification:
    • Social media intermediaries are required to take measures to verify the identity of their users, especially for significant social media intermediaries.
  • Voluntary user verification:
    • The IT Rules now allow for voluntary user verification, which means users have the option to verify their accounts with social media intermediaries using government-issued ID proofs.
  • Emergency blocking of content:
    • In cases where there is an emergency situation that threatens public order, the government can direct social media intermediaries to block access to certain content within 24 hours.
  • Data retention:
    • Social media intermediaries are required to retain user data for 180 days for investigation and prevention of cybersecurity incidents, and they are also required to provide information to the government agencies as and when requested.
  • Grievance Redressal Mechanism:
    • Social media platforms are required to establish a grievance redressal mechanism to address complaints from users and resolve them in a timely manner.
    • This aims to provide users with a channel to report objectionable content and seek remedies for any violations of their rights.
  • Code of Ethics for Digital Media:
    • The rules introduce a code of ethics for digital media, including online news portals and OTT (Over-The-Top) platforms.
    • This code includes guidelines related to the portrayal of prohibited content, journalistic conduct, and user-generated content.
    • Digital media platforms are required to classify their content into appropriate categories and follow the prescribed code of ethics.
  • Self-Regulatory Body:
    • The rules provide for the establishment of a self-regulatory body by digital media platforms, which will oversee the implementation of the code of ethics and address grievances related to digital media. Hence statement 2 is correct.
    • This self-regulatory body will be required to register with the government and comply with certain guidelines.
  • Government Oversight:
    • The rules also give the government the authority to issue directions to social media platforms and digital media platforms for compliance with the rules.
    • Failure to comply with these directions can result in penalties and other legal consequences.

Question: When was the None of the Above (NOTA) ballot option first implemented in India?
Solution:
The correct answer is 2013. Key Points:NOTA:
  • "None of the Above" (or NOTA) has been provided as an option in 2013.
  • The 'None of the Above option, simply put, gives the voter the right to express a negative opinion by not selecting any of the candidates in the fray.
  • While it may seem that NOTA has been around for a long time, it actually came into force only in 2013.
​Thus, the NOTA option was first used in the 2013 A.D. elections in India.
Important Points:
  • The first time it was used was during the Assembly elections held in Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Mizoram, and Delhi.
  • On 27 September 2013, the Supreme Court of India ruled that the right to register a "none of the above" vote in elections should apply, while ordering the Election Commission to provide a button for the same in the electronic voting machines.
  • The option of NOTA for Lok Sabha and assembly elections was prescribed by the SC in 2013.
  • The option of NOTA in Rajya Sabha polls was introduced by the EC in 2014.
Additional Information:
  • https://eci.gov.in/important-instructions/
  • 11.09.2018 - Provision for "None of the above" (NOTA) option on the ballot paper for elections to Rajya Sabha and State Legislative Council-withdrawing the provision-reg.

Question:
Which of the following is/are one of the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals?
(A) Zero Hunger
(B) Climate Action
(C) Life Below Water
(D) Quality Education
Solution:
The correct answer is A, B, C and D
Key Points: Sustainable Development Goals:
  • The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) or Global Goals are a collection of 17 interlinked global goals designed to be a "blueprint to achieve a better and more sustainable future for all".
  • The SDGs were set up in 2015 by the United Nations General Assembly and are intended to be achieved by the year 2030.
17 interlinked global goals are as follows:
  • Goal 1. End poverty in all its forms everywhere
  • Goal 2 End hunger achieve food security and improved nutrition and promote sustainable agriculture
  • Goal 3 Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
  • Goal 4 Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all
  • Goal5. Achieve gender equality and empower all women and girls
  • Goal 6 Ensure availability and sustainable management of water and sanitation for all
  • Goal 7 Ensure access to affordable, reliable, sustainable and modern energy for all
  • Goal 8 Promote sustained inclusive and sustainable economic growth, full and productive employment and decent work for all
  • Goal 9 Build resilient infrastructure, promote inclusive and sustainable industrialization and foster innovation
  • Goal 10 Reduce inequality within and among countries
  • Goal 11 Make cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient and sustainable
  • Goal 12.Ensure sustainable consumption and production patterns
  • Goal 13 Take urgent action to combat climate change and its impacts
  • Goal 14 Conserve and sustainably use the oceans, seas and marine resources for sustainable development
  • Goal 15 Protect, restore and promote sustainable use of terrestrial ecosystems, sustainably manage forests, combat desertification, and haltand+ reverse land degradation and halt biodiversity loss
  • Goal 16 Promote peaceful and inclusive societies for sustainable development, provide access to justice for all and build effective, accountable and inclusive institutions at all levels
  • Goal 17. Strengthen the means of implementation and revitalize the Global Partnership for Sustainable Development.
  • Each goal typically has 8–12 targets, and each target has between 1 and 4 indicators used to measure progress toward reaching the targets. The targets are either "outcome" targets (circumstances to be attained) or "means of implementation" targets. The latter targets were introduced late in the process of negotiating the SDGs to address the concern of some Member States about how the SDGs were to be achieved. Goal 17 is wholly about how the SDGs will be achieved.
Additional Information:
  • The 17 SDGs are (1) No Poverty, (2) Zero Hunger, (3) Good Health and Well-being, (4) Quality Education, (5) Gender Equality, (6) Clean Water and Sanitation, (7) Affordable and Clean Energy, (8) Decent Work and Economic Growth, (9) Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure, (10) Reducing Inequality, (11) Sustainable Cities and Communities, (12) Responsible Consumption and Production, (13) Climate Action, (14) Life Below Water, (15) Life On Land, (16) Peace, Justice, and Strong Institutions, (17) Partnerships for the Goals.

Question:
Match the columns.
Column - AColumn - A
i.Electric currenta.Henry
ii.Potential differenceb.Farad
iii.Capacitancec.Volt
iv.Inductanced.Ampere
OP1: i - a, ii - b, iii - c, iv - d
OP2: i - b, ii - a, iii - c, iv - d
OP3: i - d, ii - c, iii - b, iv - a
OP4: i - a, ii - c, iii - b, iv - d
Solution:
Correct Answer i - d, ii - c, iii - b, iv - a
Key Points Inductance:
  • Inductor is a device (Coil) that stores energy in the form of magnetic energy for a certain time and releases it after that time period.
  • It opposes the instantaneous change in the current flowing through the system.
  • Inductance is the tendency of an electrical conductor to oppose a change in the electric current flowing through it.
  • In honor of the physicist Heinrich Lenz, the unit of inductance is the Henry (H).
Farad:
CONCEPT:
  • Capacitor: A capacitor is a device that stores electrical energy in an electric field.
  • It is a passive electronic component with two terminals.
  • The effect of a capacitor is known as capacitance.
  • Capacitance: The capacitance is the capacity of the capacitor to store charge in it. Two conductors are separated by an insinuator (dielectric) and when an electric field is applied, electrical energy is stored in it as a charge.
    • The capacitance of a capacitor (C): The capacitance of a conductor is the ratio of charge (Q) to it by a rise in its potential (V), i.e.
    • C = Q/V
    • The unit of capacitance is the farad, (symbol F ).
    • Farad is a large unit so generally, we using μF.

EXPLANATION:
Units of capacitance:
  • The SI unit of capacitance is the farad (F), named in honor of Michael Faraday.
  • The capacitance of the conductor is 1 farad if the addition of a charge of 1 coulomb to it, increases its potential by 1 volt.
Ampere:
  • The SI unit of electric current is Ampere (A).
  • When 1 coulomb of electric charge passes through a unit region in 1 second then it is said to be 1 ampere of current.
  • i = Q/t, where I (current) in ampere, Q(charge of an electron) in Coulomb and t (time) in second.
  • An Ammeter is used to measure the electric current.
  • Coulomb (C) is the unit of electric charge.
  • Joule (J) is the SI unit of energy.
  • Volt (V) is the unit of potential difference.

Question: The Supreme Court of India rejected the plea of ___________ to quash the summons issued by the Delhi Legislative Assembly’s Committee on Peace and Harmony for inquiry related to the Delhi riots in February 2020.
Solution:
Correct Answer Facebook
Key Points
  • In August 2020, the Delhi Legislative Assembly's Committee on Peace and Harmony issued a summons to Facebook India Vice President Ajit Mohan, along with other officials of the social media giant, to appear before it to answer questions related to the alleged role of Facebook in the Delhi riots in February 2020.
  • Ajit Mohan had approached the Supreme Court of India challenging the summons, arguing that the Committee did not have the jurisdiction to issue such summons to him.
  • He was a resident of Bangalore and Facebook's India office was headquartered in Mumbai, and the Delhi Assembly's Committee could not exercise its powers beyond the territory of Delhi.
  • However, on April 22, 2021, the Supreme Court dismissed Ajit Mohan's plea and upheld the Delhi Assembly's Committee's power to summon him and other Facebook officials.
  • The Court observed that the issue of jurisdiction could not be raised at this stage and that the Committee was well within its rights to summon Ajit Mohan and seek his appearance before it.
  • The Delhi Assembly's Committee on Peace and Harmony is investigating the role of Facebook in the Delhi riots, specifically looking into allegations of hate speech and misinformation being spread on the platform during the communal violence that took place in February 2020.
Additional Information:
  • The Supreme Court, under appellate jurisdiction, conducts hearings against the courts of the lower courts.
  • Cases of High Courts are brought to the Supreme Court by constitutional, civil, criminal, and special permission.
  • In India, there are 25 High Courts, six having control over more than one State/UT.
  • Delhi the Capital of India, has a High Court of its own among the Union Territories.
  • Every High Court of India shall consist of a Chief Justice and such other judges as appointed by the President of India.
  • The Supreme Court of India is the highest judicial court under the Constitution of India.
  • Article 124 provides for the establishment and constitution of the Supreme Court.
  • It is Established as the Supreme court of India on 28th January 1950 and its Headquarters in New Delhi.
  • Also known as the 'guardian of our Constitution"
  • The chief justice of India is the head of the Supreme Court of India.
  • Justice D.Y. Chandrachud is the current 50th chief justice of India.
  • After the appointment of the new four justices on 18 September 2019, the strength of the Supreme court increases from 30 to 34.
  • Newly appointed judges Krishna Murari, SR Bhat, V Ramasubramanian, and Hrishikesh Roy.
  • The Parliament of India has the power to increase or decrease the number of judges in the Supreme court.
Important Points:In order to be named as a Judge of the Supreme Court,
  • a person must be a citizen of India and must have been a Judge of the High Court or of two or more of those Courts in succession for at least five years, or an Advocate of the High Court or of two or more of those Courts in succession for at least 10 years, or must be a distinguished jurist in the view of the President.
  • There are arrangements for the selection of a Justice of the High Court as an ad hoc Judge of the Supreme Court and for the sitting and acting of a Judge of that Court by retired Judges of the Supreme Court or High Courts.​

Question: Which crops are benefitted from the temperate cyclones arising from the Mediterranean Sea that cause rainfall in Punjab?
Solution:
The correct answer is Rabi crops.
Key Points
  • In northwestern India, some weak temperate cyclones from the Mediterranean sea cause rainfall in Punjab, Haryana, Delhi, and western Uttar Pradesh.
  • The western cyclonic disturbances which enter the Indian subcontinent from the west and the northwest during the winter months, originate over the Mediterranean Sea and are brought into India by the westerly jet stream.
  • Although the amount is meager, it is highly beneficial for rabi crops.
  • The precipitation is in the form of snowfall in the lower Himalayas.
  • It is this snow that sustains the flow of water in the Himalayan rivers during the summer months.
  • The precipitation goes on decreasing from west to east in the plains and from north to south in the mountains.
  • The average winter rainfall in Delhi is around 53 mm.
  • In Punjab and Bihar, rainfall remains between 25 mm and 18 mm respectively.
  • During October and November, the northeast monsoon while crossing over the Bay of Bengal picks up moisture and causes torrential rainfall over the Tamil Nadu coast, southern Andhra Pradesh, southeast Karnataka, and southeast Kerala.
Additional Information
  • Southwest monsoon season:
    • The period from June to September is referred to as the 'Southwest Monsoon' period.
    • The Southwest Monsoon period is the principal rainy season for the Indian subcontinent.
    • This is the summer monsoon period where the southwest monsoon holds away over the country.
    • The whole country receives nearly 75% of its rainfall during this period.

Question: The population of India is _____ according to Census 2011.
Solution:
The correct answer is 1.21 billion.
Key Points
  • India’s population has jumped to 1.21 billion, showing an increase by more than 181 million during the 2001-2011 decade, according to the data of Census 2011.
  • Though the country’s population is almost equal to the combined population of the U.S., Indonesia, Brazil, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Japan put together [1214.3 million], the silver lining is that 2001-2011 is the first decade except 1911-1921 which has actually added lesser population compared to the previous decade.
  • India’s population as per the 2011 census is​ 1210.2 million, the number of males was pegged at 623.7 million and the population of females stood at 586.5 million. Hence, Option 4 is correct.
  • The percentage growth in 2001-2011 was 17.64 – males 17.19 and females 18.12. India’s population accounts for the world’s 17.5 percent population.
Additional Information Census 2011
  • Among the States and Union Territories, Uttar Pradesh is the most populous state with 199 million people followed by Maharashtra at 112 million people and Lakshadweep is the least populated at 64,429 persons.
  • The combined population of the U.P. and Maharashtra is greater than that of the U.S.
  • The percentage of decadal growth rates of the six most populous States have declined during 2001-2011 as compared to 1991-2001.
  • The graph of population growth in U.P. shows a decline from 25.85 percent to 20.09 percent, in Maharashtra from 22.73 percent to 15.99 percent, Bihar from 28.62 percent to 25.07 percent, West Bengal from 17.77 percent to 13.93 percent, Andhra Pradesh from 14.59 percent to 11.10 percent and Madhya Pradesh from 24.26 percent to 20.30 percent.

Question:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding the Supreme Court judgement on validity of 103rd Constitutional Amendment Act?
A. The Supreme Court of India’s Constitutional Bench for this case consisted of 5 judges.
B. The Constitutional Bench upholds the 10% of EWS reservation with 3-2 majority.
C. As per the Supreme Court judgement, the 103rdConstitutional Amendment is valid although it is violating the Basic Structure of the Indian Constitution.
Solution:
The correct answer is A and B only.
Key Points
  • The 103rd Constitutional Amendment Act was passed in January 2019 and it provided for a 10% reservation in government jobs and educational institutions for economically weaker sections (EWS) of the society who are not covered under existing reservations for Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, and Other Backward Classes.
  • The main argument against the Amendment was that it violates the basic structure of the Constitution, which includes the principle of equality and the principle of reservation as enshrined in the Constitution.
  • In a landmark judgement delivered on May 5, 2021, a Constitution Bench of the Supreme Court upheld the validity of the 103rd Constitutional Amendment Act.
  • The Bench comprised of 5 Justices Ashok Bhushan, L Nageswara Rao, S Abdul Nazeer, Hemant Gupta, and S Ravindra Bhat.
  • The Supreme Court held that the 103rd Constitutional Amendment Act does not violate the basic structure of the Constitution.
  • The Court held that the principle of reservation is not an immutable feature of the Constitution and that the State has the power to provide for reservation to any socially and educationally backward class of citizens.
  • The Court also held that the 103rd Constitutional Amendment Act is a valid exercise of the State's power to provide for reservation.
  • The Constitutional Bench upholds the 10% of EWS reservation with 3-2 majority.
  • The Supreme Court also held that the 10% reservation for EWS provided under the 103rd Constitutional Amendment Act is not limited to any particular religion or caste and is available to all those who are economically backward and do not fall within the scope of the existing reservations for SCs, STs, and OBCs.
Additional Information
AmendmentYearDescription
42nd Amendment1976This amendment introduced the term "Socialist, Secular and Integrity" in the Preamble of the Constitution, and also expanded the scope of Fundamental Rights. It also gave more power to the Prime Minister and curtailed the power of the judiciary.
73rd Amendment1992This amendment provided constitutional status to Panchayati Raj Institutions (PRIs) and devolved powers and functions to them. It also reserved seats for women and Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes in the PRIs.
74th Amendment1992This amendment provided constitutional status to Urban Local Bodies (ULBs) and devolved powers and functions to them. It also reserved seats for women and Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes in the ULBs.
86th Amendment2002This amendment made education a fundamental right for children between the ages of 6 and 14. It also added Article 21A to the Constitution, which guarantees free and compulsory education to all children in this age group.
97th Amendment2011This amendment provided for the formation of co-operative societies as a fundamental right under Article 19(1)(c) of the Constitution. It also made it mandatory for states to conduct regular elections to co-operative societies.
101st Amendment2016This amendment enabled the implementation of the Goods and Services Tax (GST) in India, which replaced multiple indirect taxes with a single tax system.

Question: Who found an empirical relationship between the half-life of alpha decay and the energy of the emitted alpha particles in 1911?
Solution:
The correct answer is Geiger and Nuttall.
Key Points
  • In 1911, the New Zealand physicist Ernest Rutherford, along with his colleagues Hans Geiger and Ernest Marsden, conducted the famous gold foil experiment, which led to the discovery of the atomic nucleus.
  • During this experiment, they also found an empirical relationship between the half-life of alpha decay and the energy of the emitted alpha particles. This relationship is now known as the Rutherford's law of radioactive decay.
  • The law states that the rate of alpha decay is directly proportional to the energy of the emitted alpha particles.
  • Specifically, the law states that the logarithm of the half-life of alpha decay is linearly related to the logarithm of the energy of the emitted alpha particles.
  • The law has been found to hold true for a wide range of alpha decay processes and has been an important tool for understanding the behavior of radioactive elements.
Additional Information
ExperimentFounderDescription
Millikan Oil Drop ExperimentRobert MillikanDetermined the charge of an electron and measured the value of Planck's constant.
Rutherford Gold Foil ExperimentErnest RutherfordDiscovered the atomic nucleus and proposed the Rutherford model of the atom, which has a central nucleus with electrons orbiting around it.
Lavoisier's Oxygen Theory of CombustionAntoine LavoisierDemonstrated that combustion requires oxygen and that the mass of products formed in a chemical reaction is equal to the mass of reactants.
Haber-Bosch ProcessFritz Haber and Carl BoschDeveloped a method for synthesizing ammonia from nitrogen and hydrogen gases, which is a key component of modern fertilizers.
Faraday's Law of Electromagnetic InductionMichael FaradayDiscovered the relationship between a changing magnetic field and an induced electric current, which is the basis of electric generators and motors.
Pasteur's Experiment on FermentationLouis PasteurShowed that fermentation is caused by microorganisms and not a spontaneous chemical reaction, and also developed the process of pasteurization to kill harmful bacteria in food and drink.

Question: Nutritional care during illness is an organised group of activities which consists of all of the following except:
OP3: planning and prioritising nutrition intervention(s) to meet nutritional needs
Solution:
The correct answer is assessing psychological stress.
Key Points
  • Assessing psychological stress is an important aspect of overall health and well-being, and it can certainly impact a person's nutritional status and food choices.
  • However, it may not be considered a part of nutritional care during illness for several reasons.
  • Firstly, nutritional care during illness typically focuses on the specific nutritional needs and challenges that arise as a result of the illness itself.
    • This includes assessing the impact of the illness on a person's appetite, digestion, and nutrient requirements, as well as identifying any barriers to meeting those needs.
  • Secondly, while psychological stress can certainly impact a person's nutritional status, it may be better addressed through other means.
    • For example, a person experiencing significant stress or anxiety may benefit from counselling, stress reduction techniques, or other forms of mental health support.
  • Lastly, in some cases, addressing nutritional needs may actually help alleviate some of the symptoms of psychological stress.
    • For example, certain nutrients, such as omega-3 fatty acids and B vitamins, have been shown to have a positive impact on mood and cognitive function.
  • Overall, while assessing psychological stress may not be considered a part of nutritional care during illness, it is certainly an important aspect of overall health and well-being that should be addressed as needed.
Additional Information
  • Digestive system:
    • The food components gradually get digested as food travels through the various compartments.
    • The inner walls of the stomach and the small intestine, and the various glands associated with the canal such as salivary glands, the liver and the pancreas secrete digestive juices.
    • The digestive juices convert complex substances of food into simpler ones.
    • The digestive tract and the associated glands together constitute the digestive system.

Question: Which of the following Articles mentions about a Uniform Civil Code throughout the territory of India?
Solution:
• The correct answer is 'Article 44'.
Key Points
  • Article44 of the Indian Constitution contains the provisions regarding Uniform Civil Code for the citizens.
  • It lays down that "the State shall endeavour to secure for the citizens a uniform civil code throughout the territory of India".
  • A Uniform Civil Code means that all sections of the society irrespective of their religion shall be treated equally according to a national civil code, which shall be applicable to all uniformly.
  • They cover areas like marriage, divorce, maintenance, inheritance, adoption, and succession of the property.
  • The article corresponds with Directive Principles of State Policy.
Additional Information
ArticleProvision
Article 39
  • The State shall direct its policy towards securing:
    • that the citizens, men and women equally, have the right to an adequate means of livelihood
    • that the ownership and control of the material resources of the community are so distributed as to best serve the common good
    • that the operation of the economic system does not result in the concentration of wealth and means of production to the common detriment;
    • that there is equal pay for equal work for both men and women;
    • that the health and strength of workers, men and women, and the tender age of children are not abused and that citizens are not forced by economic necessity to enter avocations unsuited to their age or strength.
Article 40
  • The State shall take steps to organise village panchayats and endow them with such powers and authority as may be necessary to enable them to function as units of self-government.
Article 50
  • The State shall take steps to separate the judiciary from the executive in the public services of the State at all levels of the judiciary.

Question: Identify the correct statement.
OP1: Newton is a unit of force.
OP2: Newton is a unit of power.
OP3: Joule is a unit of force.
OP4: Joule is a unit of power.
Solution:
The correct answer is Newton is a unit of force.
Key Points
Force (F) is defined as the pushing or pulling of an object, due to which the motion of the body will be changed.
  • Mathematically, a force can be written as:
F = ma
Where m = mass of the body and a = acceleration of the body
  • Force is a vector quantity.
  • SI Unit of force is Newton. Therefore 1 N = 1 kg m/s2
  • In the CGS system, the absolute unit of force is dyne.
  • Therefore 1 dyne = 1 g cm/s2.

Question:
Which of the following statements is/are correct regarding the Government of India’s New Integrated Food Security Scheme?
A. This New Integrated Food Security Scheme has been started on 1 January 2023.
B. The Government of India targeted to supply food grains to more than 80 crores beneficiaries under the National Food Security Act.
C. First time this food grains supply programme was brought under the Ministry of Social Justice for effective implementation.
Solution:
The correct answer is A and B only.
Key Points
  • Centre has named the new Integrated Food Security Scheme as Pradhan Mantri Garib Kalyan Ann Yojana, PMGKAY.
  • Cabinet had approved a new integrated food security scheme for providing free foodgrains to Antodaya Ann Yojna and Primary Household beneficiaries.
  • Implementation of the new scheme started from January 1, 2023.
  • It will benefit more than 80 crore poor and the poorest of poor people.
  • The integrated scheme will strengthen the provisions of the National Food Security Act in terms of accessibility, affordability, and availability of foodgrains for the poor.
  • The Government of India targeted to supply food grains to more than 80 crores beneficiaries under the National Food Security Act.
  • The Central Government will spend more than two lakh crore rupees in 2023 as food subsidies under NFSA and other welfare schemes, to remove the financial burden of the poor and the poorest of the poor.
Additional Information
  • Union Cabinet has approved providing free foodgrains under the National Food Security Act till December 2023.
  • Addressing the media, Union Minister for Consumer Affairs, Food and Public Distribution Piyush Goyal said that around 81.35 crore beneficiaries who earlier used to procure foodgrains at subsidised rates will now get the foodgrains free of cost.
  • He said, the Centre would bear the entire cost amounting to around 2 lakh crore rupees per year.
  • The National Food Security Act 2013 (also 'Right to Food Act') is an Indian Act of Parliament which aims to provide subsidized food grains to approximately two thirds of the country's 1.2 billion people.
  • The act was signed into law on 12 September 2013, retroactive to 5 July 2013.
  • The National Food Security Act, 2013 (NFSA 2013) converts into legal entitlements for existing food security programmes of the Government of India. It includes the Midday Meal Scheme, Integrated Child Development Services scheme and the Public Distribution System.
  • Further, the NFSA 2013 recognizes maternity entitlements.
  • The Midday Meal Scheme and the Integrated Child Development Services Scheme are universal in nature whereas the PDS will reach about two-thirds of the population (75% in rural areas and 50% in urban areas).
  • Under the provisions of the bill, beneficiaries of the Public Distribution System (or, PDS) are entitled to 5 kilograms (11 lb) per person per month of cereals.

Question: The intervention of the government whether to expand demand or reduce it constitutes the ___________.
Solution:
The correct answer is Option 3.
Key Points
  • Stabilisation Function of Government Budget The government may need to correct fluctuations in income and employment.
  • The overall level of employment and prices in the economy depends upon the level of aggregate demand which depends on the spending decisions of millions of private economic agents apart from the government.
  • These decisions, in turn, depend on many factors such as income and credit availability.
  • In any period, the level of demand may not be sufficient for full utilisation of labour and otherresources of the economy.
  • Since wages and prices do not fall below a level, employment cannot be brought back to the earlier level automatically.
  • The government needs to intervene to raise the aggregate demand.
  • On the other hand, there may be times when demand exceeds available output under conditions of high employment and thus may give rise to inflation.
  • In such situations, restrictive conditions may be needed to reduce demand.
  • The intervention of the government whether to expand demand or reduce it constitutes the stabilisation function.
​Additional Information
  • The government sector affects the personal disposable income of households by making transfers and collecting taxes.
    • It is through this that the government can change the distribution of income and bring about a distribution that is considered ‘fair’ by society. This is the redistribution function.
  • Speculation involves trading a financial instrument involving high risk, in expectation of significant returns.
    • The motive is to take maximum advantage from fluctuations in the market.
  • A transaction is a monetary activity that is recorded as an entry in accounting records and has a monetary effect on the financial statements.

Question: Who had assumed the title of Balban?
Solution:
The correct answer is Option 3.
Key Points
  • After a period of chaos since the death of Razia, Ulugh Khan, one of her main opponents, consolidated power in his own hand between 1246 to 1287 CE.
  • He took the title of 'Sultan Ghiyas-ud-din Balban' on ascending the throne of the Mamluk Dynasty Delhi Sultanate in 1265 CE.
  • Another Ulugh Khan was later appointed as the governor of Awadh and eventually rose to become the Sultan of Delhi himself in Khalji Dynasty Jalal-ud-din-Khalji, ruling from 1290 to 1296 CE.
  • However, he did not assume the title of Balban, as that title was specific to the earlier Sultan, Ghiyasuddin Balban, who ruled from 1266 to 1287 CE.
​Additional Information
  • The Delhi Sultanate was a Muslim kingdom that ruled over large parts of India from 1206 to 1526 AD.
  • The sultanate was established by Qutub-ud-din Aibak, a Turkish slave general who was appointed as the governor of Delhi by the Ghurid dynasty of Afghanistan.
  • The Delhi Sultanate was divided into five dynasties: the Slave Dynasty, the Khalji Dynasty, the Tughlaq Dynasty, the Sayyid Dynasty, and the Lodi Dynasty.
  • Each dynasty was characterized by its own distinct political, social, and cultural features.
  • The Sultanate was known for its strong military and political leadership, as well as its architectural achievements.
  • The most famous architectural examples of the Delhi Sultanate are the Qutub Minar and the Alai Darwaza, both located in Delhi.
  • The Delhi Sultanate was also a period of cultural and intellectual flourishing, with notable poets, scholars, and philosophers such as Amir Khusro, Ibn Battuta, and Al-Biruni contributing to the rich intellectual and cultural heritage of the region.
  • The Delhi Sultanate was eventually replaced by the Mughal Empire in 1526, which continued to rule over India until the mid-19th century.

Question: In 1845, which German chemist published a method for the synthesis of acetic acid, a natural product containing two carbon atoms?
Solution:
The correct answer is Option 4.
Key Points
  • In 1845, the German chemist Hermann Kolbe published a method for the synthesis of acetic acid, which is a natural product containing two carbon atoms.
  • Kolbe's method involved the electrolysis of sodium acetate to produce acetic acid and carbon dioxide.
  • This was a significant breakthrough in organic chemistry, as it demonstrated that organic compounds could be synthesized from inorganic starting materials using chemical reactions.
  • Kolbe's work laid the foundation for the development of modern organic chemistry and helped to establish the concept of structural isomerism.​
Additional Information
  • Friedrich Wohler (1800-1882) was a German chemist who is best known for his synthesis of urea, which demonstrated that organic compounds could be artificially synthesized from inorganic starting materials.
    • In 1828, Wohler synthesized urea, which is a naturally occurring organic compound found in urine, from inorganic materials, namely ammonium cyanate.
  • Marcellin Berthelot (1827-1907) was a French chemist, politician, and historian of science.
    • He is best known for his work in thermochemistry, which is the study of the relationship between heat and chemical reactions.
    • Berthelot's contributions to thermochemistry helped to establish the concept of energy conservation in chemical reactions and laid the foundation for the development of the field of physical chemistry.
  • Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac (1778-1850) was a French chemist and physicist who made important contributions to the fields of chemistry and gas laws.
    • He is best known for his work on the laws governing the behavior of gases, particularly his discovery of the law of combining volumes, which states that when gases combine chemically, they do so in volumes that are in a simple ratio to one another.
    • Gay-Lussac also made significant contributions to the study of acids and bases, organic chemistry, and the chemical composition of water.
    • He is credited with the discovery of cyanogen, a compound that contains both carbon and nitrogen, and he was the first to isolate boron and to suggest that it was an element.

Question: Assume that exchange rate between the US Dollar and Indian Rupee is $1 = ₹55. Now if this exchange rate increases to $1 = ₹60, then in this case the Indian Rupee has ____ in comparison to the US dollar.
Solution:
The correct answer is Option 1.
Key Points
  • If the exchange rate between the US Dollar and Indian Rupee increases from $1 = ₹55 to $1 = ₹60, then the Indian Rupee has depreciated in comparison to the US Dollar.
  • This means that it now takes more Indian Rupees to purchase one US Dollar than before. In other words, the US Dollar has become stronger relative to the Indian Rupee.
Additional Information
  • Exchange rates fluctuate based on a variety of factors, including supply and demand, economic and political events, and central bank policies.
    • Exchange rates can have significant impacts on international trade, investment, and financial transactions.
    • For example, a strong currency may make imports cheaper but could make exports more expensive, while a weak currency can have the opposite effect.
  • The money market in India is a market where short-term financial instruments are traded.
    • It is a sub-part of the overall Indian financial system and plays a crucial role in maintaining the liquidity of the financial system.
    • The money market deals with financial instruments that have a maturity period of up to one year.
    • The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is the central bank of India and plays a crucial role in regulating the money market.
    • The RBI manages the money supply in the economy through various tools such as open market operations, bank rate, and cash reserve ratio.
    • The RBI also issues various short-term instruments such as treasury bills and manages the interest rates for short-term borrowing and lending in the economy.

Question:
Consider the following statements about the main reasons for the excessive cold in north India during the cold weather season and identify which of the statements are correct.
1. States like Punjab, Haryana and Rajasthan, being far away from the moderating influence of sea, experience continental climate.
2. The snowfall in the nearby Himalayan ranges creates a cold wave situation.
3. Around February, the cold winds coming from the Caspian Sea and Turkmenistan bring a cold wave along with frost and fog over the northwestern parts of India.
Solution:
The correct answer is Option 3.
Key Points
  • The states of Punjab, Haryana, and Rajasthan in northern India experience a continental climate due to their location far away from the moderating influence of the sea.
  • A continental climate is characterized by extreme temperatures, with hot summers and cold winters.
  • The absence of large water bodies means that these states do not experience the moderating effect of the sea, which helps to keep temperatures moderate and stable.
  • In the summer, temperatures can soar above 40°C (104°F), while in winter, they can drop below freezing point.
Additional Information
  • Snowfall in the nearby Himalayan ranges can lead to a cold wave situation in the surrounding areas.
    • This is because cold air is transported from the higher altitude regions to the lower altitude areas, leading to a drop in temperature.
    • During the winter months, when the snowfall is at its peak in the Himalayan ranges, the temperature in the surrounding areas can drop significantly.
    • The cold air mass moves downwards due to the force of gravity, causing the temperature to fall rapidly.
  • The Western Disturbance is a cyclonic storm that originates in the Mediterranean region and moves towards India, bringing with it cold air from the Caspian Sea and Turkmenistan.
    • This weather pattern can result in heavy snowfall in the higher altitudes of the Himalayas and cause a drop in temperature in the plains, leading to frost and fog in some areas.
    • The Western Disturbance is an important source of winter precipitation for the northwestern parts of India and plays a crucial role in the region's agriculture and water supply.

Question: In which year, the Koya rebellion took place in the eastern Godavari tract?
Solution:
The correct answer is Option 3.
Key Points
  • The Koya rebellion took place in the eastern Godavari tract in the years 1879-1880.
  • The rebellion was led by the Koya tribe, who were protesting against the oppressive policies of the British colonial administration, including the imposition of taxes, forced labor, and the destruction of their traditional way of life.
  • The Koya rebellion was a part of a larger movement of tribal uprisings that took place in colonial India in the 19th century, and was one of the last major tribal revolts against the British before India gained independence in 1947.
  • Despite putting up a fierce resistance, the Koya rebels were eventually defeated by the British, who used their military might to crush the uprising.
Additional Information
  • The British rule in India began in 1757 with the Battle of Plassey, when the British East India Company gained control of the Bengal region of India.
  • Over time, the British expanded their control over the Indian subcontinent through a combination of military conquest, diplomacy, and political manipulation.
  • By the mid-19th century, the British had established a colonial administration in India and controlled most of the territory through a system of direct and indirect rule.
  • British colonialism in India had a profound impact on the country's social, economic, and political structures.
  • The British introduced modern education, law, and administrative systems, which brought about significant changes in Indian society.
  • However, they also exploited India's resources and imposed oppressive policies that led to widespread poverty, famine, and social unrest.
  • The Indian independence movement, which began in the late 19th century, sought to end British rule in India and establish a free and independent India.
  • The movement was led by Indian nationalist leaders such as Mahatma Gandhi, Jawaharlal Nehru, and Subhash Chandra Bose, who used nonviolent protests and civil disobedience to challenge British authority.
  • India finally gained independence from British rule on August 15, 1947, following a long and difficult struggle for freedom.

Question: Α _________ is a networking device that filters network traffic while connecting multiple computers or communicating devices.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 3, i.e., Switch.Key Points
  • Connecting device:
    • Devices that are used to connect other devices are called connecting devices. Types of connecting devices are:
    • Repeater:
      • A repeater is a device that receives signals and before it becomes too weak or corrupted the repeater regenerates the original bit pattern and sends the data.
      • It is like a refreshing station for data while travelling.
    • Hub:
      • A hub is a multiport repeater.
      • A hub can connect more than two segments of a LAN where a repeater can connect only two segments.
      • It also does not have any filtering capabilities like a repeater.
    • Bridge:
      • A bridge operates in both the physical layer and the data link layer.
      • As a physical layer device, it can regenerate bits and as a data link layer device, it can check the physical addresses contained in the frame.
      • Bits can be carried to any distance by using properly spaced repeaters, but the collision domain will not allow this and that’s why Bridge are required.
    • Router:
      • A router is a three-layer device; physical, data link and network layer.
      • As a physical layer device, it can regenerate a bit, as a data link layer device the router can check the physical addresses contained in a packet and as a network layer device, it can check the network layer addresses (addresses in IP layer).
    • Switch:
      • ​A switch is a networking device that connects multiple devices together and filters network traffic to ensure that data is sent to the correct destination.
      • It operates at the data link layer of the OSI model, and it uses the physical addresses (MAC addresses) of devices to make forwarding decisions. Switches are commonly used in local area networks (LANs) to connect computers, printers, and other devices.
Additional Information
  • Connecting devices are bridges between the different parts of a document that tie all of the pieces together into one coherent package.
  • Connecting devices show the reader how various sections of information are related, and they help keep the reader on track with the flow of information.
  • Documents which do not include connecting devices are disjointed, choppy and difficult to read.
  • Connecting devices are analogous to the traffic signals people rely on when driving.
  • Imagine a major metropolitan area, such as Seattle, without bridges, traffic signs or traffic lights to guide drivers through traffic.
  • The same is true of a document that lacks connecting devices: the reader will have a difficult time following the writer's train of thought and the document will not flow smoothly.
Note: Distributor is not a common networking term, but it could refer to a device that distributes power or signals to multiple devices.

Question: Which of the following is not a LibreOffice Software Suite program?
Solution:
LibreOffice is a free and open-source office suite, consisting of several applications for word processing, spreadsheets, presentations, graphics, and databases.
  • The correct option is 2) LibreOffice Excel, as Excel is a proprietary spreadsheet application developed by Microsoft and not a part of the LibreOffice suite.

Question: Which among the following is not a magnetic storage?
Solution:
• Winchester disk: A Winchester disk, also known as a hard disk drive, is a magnetic storage device that stores and retrieves digital information using rapidly rotating disks coated with magnetic material.
  • Floppy Drive: A floppy disk drive is a magnetic storage device that uses a flexible, removable disk coated with magnetic material to store and retrieve digital information.
  • Memory Card: A memory card is a solid-state storage device that uses flash memory to store and retrieve digital information. It does not use magnetic storage technology.
  • Magnetic Tape: Magnetic tape is a magnetic storage medium that uses a long, narrow strip of plastic coated with magnetic material to store and retrieve digital information.
So, the correct option is 3) Memory Card, as it is not a magnetic storage device.

Question: Which among the following type of computer is also known as notebook?
Solution:
• A Laptop notebook computer is a battery- or AC-powered personal computer generally smaller than a briefcase that can easily be transported and conveniently used in temporary spaces such as on aeroplanes, in libraries, temporary offices, and at meetings.
  • A notebook computer sometimes called a laptop computer, typically weighs less than 5 pounds and is 3 inches or less in thickness.

Question: _______ is the bit-rate of available or consumed information capacity expressed typically in metric multiples of bits per second.
Solution:
• In computing, bandwidth is the bit-rate of available or consumed information capacity expressed typically in metric multiples of bits per second.
  • Variously, bandwidth may be characterized as network bandwidth, data bandwidth, or digital bandwidth.
  • This definition of bandwidth is in contrast to the field of signal processing, wireless communications, modem data transmission, digital communications, and electronics, in which bandwidth is used to refer to analog signal bandwidth measured in hertz, meaning the frequency range between lowest and highest attainable frequency while meeting a well-defined impairment level in signal power.

Question: ________ holds address of the active memory location.
Solution:
The correct answer is Memory address register.
Key Points
  • In a computer, the Memory Address Register (MAR) is the CPU register that stores either the memory address from which data will be brought to the CPU registers or the address to which data will be sent and stored via the system bus.
Additional Information
  • In computing, the instruction register (IR) is the part of a CPU's control unit that holds the instruction currently being executed or decoded.
    • In simple processors, each instruction to be executed is loaded into an instruction register, which it holds while it is decoded, prepared and eventually executed, which may have several steps.
  • The Output Registers (OR) hold the output after processing the input data.
  • A memory buffer register is a register in a computer's processor, or central processing unit, CPU, that transfers data to and from an immediate access store.

Question: Which of the following shortcut key is used to select all cells of the current row in MS - Excel 2010 worksheet?
Solution:
The correct answer is Shift+Spacebar.
Key Points
  • The Shift+Spacebar keyboard shortcut in Excel 2010 is used to select all cells of the current row.
  • Ctrl+Spacebar shortcut selects the entire column.
  • Clicking ctrl+spacebar once selects the table column data whereas clicking crtl+spacebar twice selects the entire table column.
  • You can also do this by clicking the top edge of the column header in the table.
Additional Information
  • To select a table row, click the first cell in the table row, then click the ctrl+shift+right arrow.
  • To select all rows and columns, click anywhere in the table and click ctrl+A.
  • Ctrl+Alt+F9 shortcut calculates all worksheets in all open workbooks, regardless of whether they have changed since their last calculation.
  • F9 shortcut calculates all worksheets in all workbooks.

Question: _________ records everything you type on your PC in order to obtain your log-in name, passwords and other sensitive information.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 2.
Concept:
Keyloggers, also known as keystroke loggers, are software applications or hardware devices that record the activity (keys tapped) on a keyboard. Keyloggers are a type of spyware in which users are unaware that their actions are being recorded.
Spyware: Spyware is a type of malicious software or malware that is installed on a computing device without the end user's knowledge.
Keyloggers Characteristics:
  • Keyloggers are a type of malware.
  • Keyloggers are a particularly insidious type of spyware that can record and steal consecutive keystrokes (and much more) that the user enters on a device.
  • The term keylogger, or "keystroke logger," is self-explanatory: Software that logs what you type on your keyboard.
  • However, keyloggers can also enable cybercriminals to eavesdrop on you, watch you on your system camera, or listen over your smartphone's microphone.
  • Keyloggers may be used for a number of objectives, including fraudulently gaining access to your private information and monitoring staff actions. Some keyloggers may also record your screen at random intervals; these are known as screen recorders.
  • A keylogger is a malicious computer application that records everything you write on the keyboard and learns the keystroke pattern, including words, characters, and symbols, and then sends all of the recorded information to hostile hackers.
Hence the correct answer is option 2.

Question: Crypto Locker is a form of which of the following?
Solution:
Correct Answer 1. Ransomware
CryptoLocker ransomware is a file-encrypting ransomware, which encrypts the personal documents found on victim's computer using RSA-2048 key (AES CBC 256-bit encryption algorithm), then displays a message which offers to decrypt the data if a payment of about 2.05 Bitcoins, or approximately $1300 is made.
Important Points
Let us explain each term:
Ransomware: Ransomware is a type of malicious software (malware) that encrypts a user's data.
  • The attacker then demands a ransom from the victim to restore access to the data upon payment.
  • CryptoLocker is a notorious example of this type of malware.
  • It propagates usually via malicious email attachments and when activated, encrypts certain types of files on the system using RSA public key cryptography, with the private key stored only on the malware's control servers.
  • The malware then displays a message which offers to decrypt the data if a payment (through either Bitcoin or a pre-paid cash voucher) is made by a stated deadline.

Adware: Adware is a type of software that automatically delivers advertisements. It is usually unwanted, as it can be intrusive and harm your computer.
  • Some adware can also be a form of spyware—programs designed to monitor users' web browsing to display unwanted advertisements.
  • However, not all adware has malicious intent and some businesses genuinely use it as a method for generating advertising revenue.

Spyware: Spyware is a type of malware that is installed on a computer without the user's knowledge in order to collect their personal information, details about their internet usage, and other important data.
  • Spyware is used for many purposes.
  • Usually, it aims to track and sell your internet usage data, capture your credit card or bank account information, or steal your personal identity.

Worms: A worm is a standalone malware computer program that replicates itself in order to spread to other computers.
  • It often uses a computer network to spread itself, relying on security failures on the target computer to access it.
  • Unlike a virus, it does not need to attach itself to an existing program.
  • Worms almost always cause at least some harm to the network, if only by consuming bandwidth, whereas viruses almost always corrupt or modify files on a targeted computer.

Question: Which one of the following folders is used to store deleted emails?
Solution:
The correct option is (1)
Trash
Key Points
  • A message that you delete remains in your trash for 30 days. It will be permanently erased after that point.
  • On Gmail and Google Apps, an archived message defaults to the Archive folder or All Mail while a deleted message goes into the trash folder.
  • Your deleted emails can be automatically removed from your trash folder permanently depending on your email provider or company's policies (often after 30 days).
  • Check your Gmail inbox now. There is a list of folders on the left side of the screen (Inbox, Starred, Spam, etc). Your deleted emails will be located in a folder labeled "Trash" or "Bin" (the name of the folder depends on the user's language preferences).
Additional Information
Inbox:- a location on a computer where emails sent to you are stored.
Outbox:- Without an internet connection, users can read, reply to, and delete emails. All of your emails from the outbox are immediately sent whenever you're back online. Your emails might still be sitting in Gmail's outbox if you've been using this feature.
Spam:- Email spam, commonly referred to as junk email, is the practice of sending unwanted email messages in mass to a large list of subscribers.

Question: Which among the following ports is also called as mouse port?
Solution:
The correct answer is PS/2
Key Points
  • There are various types of computer ports such as USB ports, Ethernet ports, PS/2 ports, VGA ports etc.
  • The DIN is a round connector with pins arranged in a circular pattern used for connecting PC keyboards, MIDI instruments etc.
  • Mini DIN connectors are small in size compared to regular DINs, but the pins are arranged horizontally unlike in normal DIN.
  • PS/2 or PS/02 is a DIN connector available with 6 pins. It is used to connect keyboards and mice and was developed by IBM. Hence option 4 is correct.
  • These ports are available in different colours like purple for the keyboard and green for the mouse.
Additional Information
  • The Video Graphics Array or VGA port is a 3-row 15-pin connector. It is used in monitors, video cards, projectors etc. This port carries video signals up to 648X480 resolution.
  • The function of the USB ports is to connect computer peripherals like printers, keyboards, external hard drives etc.
  • The Ethernet port is used as a network cable to the PC. It establishes an internet connection to the computer. It is a Local Area Network or LAN.

Question: _________ displays a list of utility configure the computer system and install software and hardware.
Solution:
The correct option is "Control Panel".
  • Control Panel is a built-in feature in the Windows operating system that provides a centralized location to configure and manage various settings for the computer system, as well as to install software and hardware.
  • It contains a variety of applets or utilities, each of which provides access to specific settings or tasks.
  • Examples of applets in the Control Panel include "Programs and Features", which allows you to install and uninstall programs, "Device Manager", which allows you to manage hardware devices installed on the computer, "Display Settings", which allows you to adjust the display resolution and other settings, and "User Accounts", which allows you to manage user accounts on the computer.
Additional Information
  • Help and Support is a feature that provides access to help documentation and support resources for Windows and other software applications. It contains a variety of articles, tutorials, and troubleshooting guides to help users resolve common issues and learn how to use different features of the operating system and applications.
  • Taskbar is a bar that appears at the bottom of the Windows desktop, displaying a list of open programs and providing quick access to various system settings and features, such as the Start menu, notifications, and system tray.
  • Run is a feature that allows you to quickly open and run programs, files, and system commands by typing in their names or file paths in the "Run" dialog box. It is accessed by pressing the "Windows key + R" keyboard shortcut.

Question: _________ was the first browser to display images inline with text instead of displaying images in a separate window.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 2.
Key Points
  • Mosaic was the first web browser to display images alongside text, as opposed to in a separate window.
  • It was the first browser to achieve widespread popularity when it was released in 1993.
  • Mosaic was created by Marc Andreessen and Eric Bina at the University of Illinois at Urbana-National Champaign's Center for Supercomputing Applications (NCSA).
Additional Information
  • In 2002, Mozilla, an open-source web browser, was initially released. It is based on the same codebase as Netscape Navigator and was developed by the Mozilla Foundation.
  • The text-based web browser Lynx was initially released in 1992. It is intended for visually impaired users or those who prefer a simplified browsing experience.
  • Opera is a web browser that was released for the first time in 1995. It is renowned for its speed and security features, in addition to its support for cutting-edge web technologies.

Question: ________ are a set of wires, which carries a group of bits in parallel and has an associated control scheme. It provides a communication path between two or more devices of a computer system.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 1.
Buses are a set of wires, which carries a group of bits in parallel and has an associated control scheme. It provides a communication path between two or more devices of a computer system. The bus transmits data, memory addresses, and control signals between the CPU, memory, and I/O devices, among other computer components.
Additional Information
  • Control unit is a CPU component that manages the data flow between the CPU and other devices. It interprets instructions retrieved from memory and generates control signals to direct the operation of other computer components.
  • Register is a small amount of fast memory used to temporarily store data in the CPU during processing. Registers can store data, address information, and control signals.
  • Cache is a small, high-speed memory used to temporarily store frequently accessed data or instructions in order to facilitate faster access. The cache is situated near the CPU to reduce access times.

Question:
What will the function given below return in MS-Excel 2010?
=MATCH (12, {10,13, 30, 40, 60},1)
Solution:
MATCH function
  • The MATCH function in Excel is used to locate a specific item within a range of cells. In this case, the function is looking for the position of the number 12 in the array ten, thirteen, thirty, forty, and sixty.
  • The MATCH function has the following syntax: =MATCH (lookup value, lookup array, [match type], lookup value).
  • So, =MATCH (12, {10,13, 30, 40, 60},1) will return 1.
  • Here, the lookup value in this case is 12, and the lookup array is 10, 13, 30, 40, 60. The match type is set to 1, which means that the function will search the lookup array for the largest value that is less than or equal to the lookup value. Because the number 12 is less than the array's first value (10), the function returns the position of the array's first number, which is 1.

Question: Which among the following statements is incorrect for input devices?
OP1: Input devices are also called as peripheral device.
OP3: Input devices helps computer in receiving data.
OP4: Optical Mark Reader is an input device.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 1.
Key Points
  • Input devices include keyboards, scanners, mice, joysticks, OMR (Optical Marker Reader), and digital cameras.
  • The input device, which is the hardware used to accept data from people, is referred to as the input unit of a computer. Human input is transformed into data that computers can understand by input devices.
  • The most frequent and well-liked input method for entering data into computers is the keyboard.
  • Text, photos, videos, and sounds can all be submitted into a computer system using an input device. The most popular method for entering text is the keyboard.
  • An input device is a piece of computer hardware used to provide control and data signals to a data processing system, such as a computer or information appliance.
Additional Information
Peripheral devices: A computer peripheral is any external device that provides input and output for the computer.
  • Peripheral devices connect with a computer through several I/O interfaces, such as communications (COM), Universal Serial Bus (USB) and serial ports such as serial advanced technology attachment (SATA) ones.
    • An Input peripheral device sends data or instructions to the computer.
      • Examples of Input peripheral devices are mouse, keyboard, image scanner, barcode reader, light pen, microphone, digital camera, webcam, dance pad, and read-only memory.
    • An output peripheral device provides output from the computer.
      • Examples of output peripheral devices are computer monitors, projectors, printers, headphones, and computer speakers.
Hence, the correct answer is option 1.

Question: Which among the following statements is incorrect?
OP1: A magnetic tape consists of vertical columns called frames.
OP2: Magnetic tape consists of horizontal rows called channels or tracks.
OP3: Magnetic tape drivers are suitable for storage of data that need to be accessed randomly.
OP4: There is no addressing in the magnetic tapes.
Solution:
Magnetic Tape
Magnetic tape data storage is a system for storing digital information on magnetic tape using digital recording.
A magnetic tape consists of vertical columns called frames.
  • Frames: The vertical partitions of magnetic tape are called frames.
  • Tracks: The horizontal partitions of magnetic tape are called tracks or channels.
Magnetic tape drivers are suitable for storage of data that need to be accessed randomly.
This statement is not correct.
  • Magnetic tape drives are sequential access devices, meaning that data is accessed sequentially from the beginning to the conclusion of the tape.
  • This renders them unsuitable for storing data that requires random access, such as in a database.
There is no addressing in the magnetic tapes.
This statement is also correct.
  • Typically, magnetic tapes are organized as a series of blocks or frames containing data, but there is no addressing mechanism that allows specific data to be quickly located.
  • Instead, data must be sequentially read or written from the beginning to the end of the tape.
Hence, the correct answer is option 3.
